body:
That sounds absolutely right, there may be more limbo cases like this one in the dependency engine. We do not use a lot of branching at Airbnb so this hasn't come up yet on our side.

Please send a PR!

I'm extremely afraid of things that make it easy to nuke everything. Muscle memory and context shift don't play well together. Someone developing a plugin nuked production a few months back with a resetdb. I prefer not spending time restoring backups and playing catchup.

Write yourself a script, name it `jack_nukes_airflow_dev.py`, hardcode the connection string in there and don't share it with anyone :)

No worries, just thought it might be useful to add a "keep connections" parameter in `airflow resetdb`

Running `delete from log; delete from job; delete from dag; delete from dag_pickle; delete from task_instance; delete from job;` seems to have stuffed up all my charts, so its probably not a good to do that :+1:
The PR you described is welcomed!
![img](http://replygif.net/i/1420.gif)
I would bless a PR doing all this :)
This is not possible at the moment. Plugin code should be pretty static...
The above fix solved our problems.
@jlowin , any suggestions?
I'm wondering if this works with when `fernet_key = cryptography_not_found_storing_passwords_in_plain_text` (default when crytography isn't installed). Would the warning be silenced?
We don't use LDAP authentication or Postgres at Airbnb, so we can't help much...

@hirolau what version of airflow? this issue was fixed after the release of 1.6.1
@mistercrunch

This doesn't influence how the fernet key gets computed, so everything still works with or without crypto. The warning was simply occurring (on `configuration.py:345`) because someone was trying to access the `fernet_key` entry of the config but it didn't exist (in the `TEST_CONFIG`). It wasn't especially linked to the fact that crypto was installed or not.
What version of python?

Basically "airflow" is not in the path of your worker. And your have to make sure it is.

Is your airflow installed globally? What user are you running your worker under? If not root (which I would suggest) you will need to change to this user fully (ie. su - airflow). Did you test your script under this user?
@mistercrunch anything left to do?

My startup script runs as root but changes to the airflow user. I've added a couple of print statements and the AIRFLOW_HOME env variable seems to be present which is rather confusing... 

Commenting out the serve logs call seems to allow the worker to start, but this isn't a great solution ðŸ™

It's good to go!
![img](http://reactiongifs.us/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/youre_awesome_carl_sagan.gif)

If no DagRun and task instances exist for a DAG, the first DagRun gets seeded on the min(start_date). 

If there are task instances, the first DagRun is created a few runs before the most recent task instance (5 I believe). This was an arbitrary attempt at keeping the flow when people migrated from `1.4` to `1.5`. It's not perfect, but it worked for most of our 100+ DAGs with little work.

I'm guessing that when you cleared everything, you might have left some orphan task instances behind. Task instances linked to task_ids that are no longer. Anyhow, we shouldn't account for those when getting the set of tasks but we do. You can see those on the "Task Instances" view in the UI, they'll show up there even if the tasks have been removed from your DAG.

Here's a link to the related code:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/jobs.py#L378

A line that would say `.filter(TI.task_id.in_(DAG.task_ids))` would help disregarding the orphan task_ids...

The `depends_on_past` logic is somewhat easy to understand though sometimes tricky to deal with. Those tasks depend on the success of their immediate previous instance, except for the start_date since it needs to start somewhere AND for the start_date of a backfill command since otherwise your backfill may never start.
Seems like its only for tasks where depends_on_past is not true.
The exception `UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\x98' in position 27: ordinal not in range(128)` may point the way? Perhaps you have garbage in your connect string.
/cc @moertel

- After seeing coveralls fail because the code coverage went down, I found out that the tests in `tests/models.py` were actually not getting found and executed by nose. I fixed it by adding `from .models import *` in `tests/__init__.py`, like it was already done for `core.py`.
- Once the new tests were included, I had to remove some leading zeros in the previously ignored test that Python 3 didn't like.

Yes you will need to run it constantly as the scheduler triggers the running of jobs. You can compare it to cron but it is just a bit more sophisticated. It is pretty light weight so the scheduler itself should not end up in performance issues quickly. 

To run it as a daemon you need to wrap it in a init.d script or use a systemd unit. For systemd unit have a look in the scripts/systemd directory.
@mistercrunch can this PR be merged?
Good catch.
Looms like lines 223-224 aren't needed anymore...

append_only_new acts as a static method, so I'm not sure how referencing `self` or `task` matters. It's general purpose enough that it could be moved to `airflow.utils`.

This is out of scope for this PR, but both these lists should actually be sets, it might actually make parsing large DAGs significantly faster.

Yes, I agree, we could move the methods to utils. Though if we do that we would have to make the error message generic too.

I'd rather have two methods `append_only_new_downstream` and `append_only_new_upstream` that would add the elements to the corresponding protected list of `self`. I feel it would be more object oriented and would remove the need to pass the protected list as an argument, even though it would duplicate some code. Or like `_set_relatives`, we could pass a boolean argument `upstream` to indicate which list to add the element too, still without having to past the protected list as an argument.

What do you think ?
@mistercrunch Removed lines 223-224
I was using 1.6. Thanks for fixing this issue!

Connection string: `postgresql+psycopg2://airflow:My!Secret&%password@my-domain.com:5432/airflow`, so using psycopg2. The error is for a start of string character so I don't think its a problem with bad stuff in the string.
We're closing this PR as we already have a second version (with dag testing through `SchedulerJob`) that has somewhat diverged from this one.

OK, so I switched the metadata DB to mysql and discovered that the DB was not being initialised properly during the build process. Could be that this was the problem with postgres as well and it was just giving a rather obscure error message?

Hmn.. we (Agari) use postgresql for the metadataDB.Do you always run upgradeDB? I'm pulling HEAD master, though the last time I did such a pull was 2 weeks ago. What version of the code are you running?

@mistercrunch @thibault-ketterer sorry for the delay -- my suggestion is to add `line = line.decode()` at line 72 of `bash_operator.py`. This should be python2 and 3 compatible and cleanly convert the bytes to str as desired.

So the loop will be:

``` python
                for line in iter(sp.stdout.readline, b''):
                    line = line.decode() # NEW LINE
                    logging.info("{}".format(line.strip()))

```

Great! The class level `logger` is super. Couple of comments:
- Do you want to be changing the logging level of the root logger vs the Airflow logger?
- `self.logger` might be best as a `property`?
- The `self.log_info` seems like a fair amount of sugar vs just `self.logger.info`

Have you considered configuring from a file? We followed something similar to this: http://victorlin.me/posts/2012/08/26/good-logging-practice-in-python, which we found both abstracted and versatile, given that the logging configs are separated from the code. But it's a bit more involved.
Nice, sorry about the lag in merging, please send a new PR and I'll find time to review it.

Ok, that makes sense -- is there any reason to keep that code around right now?
Also, it seems like it only schedules extra tasks for where depends_on_past is not True?

@MaximilianR , thanks for your feedback!

> self.logger might be best as a property?
> The self.log_info seems like a fair amount of sugar vs just self.logger.info

Yes, thanks! I updated the code. I was striving to make this class as easy to use as possible, your suggestion lets me achieve this while making the code shorter.

> Do you want to be changing the logging level of the root logger vs the Airflow logger?
> Have you considered configuring from a file?

I agree these would be good improvements, though in order to keep each PR small and incremental, I'd rather keep them for later. 

The current code is already configuring the root logger programmatically (in `log_to_stdout()` in [cli.py](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/732297b7f561c4b647b3557a841525b514fe64c0/airflow/bin/cli.py) ) and tries to override the log level for the tests with `--logging-level=DEBUG` in [run_unit_tests.sh](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/732297b7f561c4b647b3557a841525b514fe64c0/run_unit_tests.sh). 

All I'm doing is improving things a bit by making making sure that each logger has a proper name + that the `--logging-level=DEBUG` is effective. I think we can build up on top of this in order to move the whole log config to a file, and it will require to carefully re-do all the logic with the different logging format specified in [cli.py](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/732297b7f561c4b647b3557a841525b514fe64c0/airflow/bin/cli.py) + probably provide a different config file for the Travis builds to re-obtain the `--logging-level=DEBUG` behaviour currently used during the tests. 

I'd rather not include that change in the present PR though.
@svendx4f Thanks, looks great!
1.6.1. Had not been running upgradeDB. We switched to mySQL and it works fine. I suspect that the DB was not initialised properly and that it was just a weird error message.

I've updated the PR

@mistercrunch Also fixed a second bug which effectively made the num_runs parameter compulsory.

schedule_interval is now a DAG object argument, not a task object argument.

default_args or the DAG is a dictionary of defaults for task level arguments

```
DAG("mydagid", schedule_interval='@daily', default_args=d)
```

where the dict `d` does NOT contain schedule_interval

We used to allow for tasks on different schedule_interval in the same DAG, but that was confusing so now we enforce it as a DAG level param.

Just rebased to solve conflicts. @mistercrunch, since the changes discussed here don't actually change anything, or you okay to merge as is or would you prefer me to rollback a bit and only add the unit tests ?

https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/652

After some trial and error, it appears DAG objects are only collected into the DagBag if they're referenced as a module local variable.  Since dag configuration is pure python code, it is quite possible (if not entirely straightforward) to programmatically build variant DAGs.

```
create_dags = ['first_dag', 'second_dag']
for dag_name in create_dags:
    new_dag = DAG(
        dag_name,
        start_date=start_date,
        schedule_interval=schedule_interval,
        default_args=default_args
    )
    locals()[dag_name] = new_dag
    del new_dag
```
I registered a new dag. This dag will be external triggered, so I dont need to schedule it. How can I make the scheduler ignore it (nto schedule it and just run when i trigger it).

sudo start-stop-daemon --start --chuid ubuntu --quiet --pidfile $PIDFILE --exec $DAEMON
See #717. You're missing stuff in your path

```
LOGGING_LEVEL = configuration.get('core', 'LOGGING_LEVEL')
```

and set the default to logging.INFO

What is the correct way (if exists one) to trigger a dag when a file is uploaded on AWS S3, for example?
Is it better to create a scheduled job that makes pooling on S3?

I could start a dag with a S3Sensor, and makes the task wait_for_downstream=true.
So the task will be scheduled again just when the downstream terminates. So I will process the file just once.

@pedrorjbr what has changed in your daemon script? Those two commands look the same to me excluding `sudo`. Is sudo even required as on boot the init.d scripts will be run as root (unless manually run)?

My script looks something like the following

```
PROG="/usr/local/bin/airflow"
PROG_ARGS="worker" 
PID_PATH="/var/run"
PID_NAME="airflow-worker.pid"
AIRFLOW_USER="ubuntu"
LOG_FILE="/var/log/airflow/airflow_worker.log"

source "/home/$AIRFLOW_USER/.profile"

start() {
    start-stop-daemon --start --background --pidfile "$PID_PATH/$PID_NAME" --make-pidfile --user $AIRFLOW_USER --chuid $AIRFLOW_USER --startas /bin/bash -- -c "exec $PROG $PROG_ARGS > $LOG_FILE 2>&1"
}

stop() {
    start-stop-daemon --stop --pidfile "$PID_PATH/$PID_NAME" --retry 10
}

check_user() {
    if [ "$(id -u)" != "0" ]; then
        echo "This script must be run as root" 1>&2
        exit 1
    fi
}

# Other stuff here

case "$1" in
    start)
        check_user
        start
        exit 0
    ;;
    stop)
        check_user
        stop
        exit 0
    ;;
    reload|restart|force-reload)
        stop
        start
        exit 0
    ;;
    status)
        status
        exit $?
    ;;
    **)
        echo "Usage: $0 {start|stop|reload|status}" 1>&2
        exit 1
    ;;
esac
```

Heres an extract of my users profile too (note the `PATH` hasn't been changed as `/usr/local/bin` should already be on the path)

```
export AIRFLOW_HOME=/home/ubuntu/airflow
export AIRFLOW_DAGS=${AIRFLOW_HOME}/dags
```
Looks reasonable. Mergin'

Ah, got it. The BQ connection does not implement this. I suppose we could wrap the BQ connection in our own custom PEP-0249 implementation, but I'll leave that for a separate ticket.

Note that this can't apply to DagRun started before this feature is deployed since it's based on a new start_date field in DagRun

Hi, 

Sorry about this, yes, I understand there's indeed something wrong.

The `log_to_stdout` was already there before, in [cli.py](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/740/files#diff-1c2404a3a60f829127232842250ff406L41), [the new version](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/740/files#diff-4e0d28e629c45c2e3baf0a60766281e9R754)  is almost identical, and the logs don't seem to be missing [in Travis](https://travis-ci.org/airbnb/airflow/jobs/95616716#L1484).

The log setup is duplicated in several places, in cli.py, airflow.py and utils.py, I guess I missed something somewhere. 

I'm having atm, give me a sec..
Thanks for fixing this up.
Old, closing for now

@svendx4f Whether or not log_to_stdout was there previously, it's completely unnecessary to attempt reinitialisation in all those places. It's much cleaner to just initialise once, in a place that can be reasonably customised. The code in #752 is cleaner, allows local overrides, and works.
@mistercrunch @MaximilianR Thank you for merging this
@mtustin-handy don't thank me!

Thanks for looking into that @mtustin-handy, I'm happy to hear your PR is solving this. 

The logic in cli.py was initialising the logs in several places and in different ways, among other things with different logging format. 

I totally agree it's cleaner to have one single configuration approach for the whole project. 

I think we now have the loggers named after the containing file instead of the class as before (cf [this travis log](https://travis-ci.org/airbnb/airflow/jobs/96166494#L1204)) , it is the intended behaviour ? Or is the behaviour different in your runtime?
`return contrib.hooks.BigQueryHook(bigquery_conn_id=self.conn_id)` is fine by me

Now the loggers are named after the fully qualified names of the classes.
That is, module + class.
